WorkItem.ClosedComment: Declining this. While it would be a useful thing to have, there's no immediate solution as to how to display it (even with the suggestions provided).
WorkItem.Description:
It would be really nice if the Direct Upgrade and optimized Upgrade List could show the model-defined subpoints instead of just the sum.
Â 
A lot of times I want to know /why/ something is an upgrade. Especially for tank models (I'd rather have a smaller survival/mitigation upgrade than a larger threat upgrade, for example). Also, some other models (/looks at Enhance and RestoSham >.>) don't let you nullify Survivability or have a "Burst" subpoint and expect you to just sort everything by DPS/Sustained value, which is annoying and renders the upgrade list features effectively useless as the upgrade value is fuged by the survival/burst value, wich can sometimes be /huge/, in the case of burst.
WorkItem.Summary: [Feature Request.Optimizer.UL] Upgrade List breakdown by Subpoints

Comments.Message: The problem is that an item can be a 400 overall upgrade, by being a 500 mitigation upgrade, and a 100 survival downgrade. Displaying that is rather difficult.
Can't it just be displayed the same way the normal gear charts are, except using the currently equipped item as the base value? It should still make sense when sorted by overall.

Think about what you're asking, and re-read what I said; I'm guessing you misunderstood. 

It's true that our charts do at least support negative values, but unless it's either all negative or all posative, there's no way to visually tell where the overall value is. This would be extremely confusing for almost all users. A bar that visually shows a Survivability of 300 and a Mitigation of 200, for a Total of 500 is easy. It's just a bar that's 500pixels long, with the first 300 of it shaded blue, and the rest (200) shaded red. But a bar that shows a Survivability of 500, and a Mitigation of -100, for a Total of 400... Not so easy. What does that look like? There's no immediately obvious answer to that (that I know of anyway), so it's a situation we try to avoid where possible.

Ah, I see what you're saying now. That makes sense.

Hmm. How to tackle this problem...

You could have the negative values stack up left of zero, then have the positive values stack up starting from that negative-most value.  The negatives could be half-height, so that there's still room to put the numbers.

One display possibility, if you have positive and negative components, and the sum is positive:

1) Display the positive components normally, but half-height (bar left-justified, grows to the right)
2) Display the negative components, half-height, just below the positive components, and right justified (so the right-end of both bars is at the same X position).
3) The left end of the negative bar is the total.  You should have a thick vertical bar at that position:

Example:

11111!1111
00000!2222

1 =  positive = +9 survival
2 = negative = -4 mitigation
0 = whitespace (to get my example to align)
! = vertical "total score" = 5

This starts to break down if the components have a much larger value than the total (1000000 - 999999) but I wouldn't expect that for realistic gear values.
